awd_abstract_narration:
Dense stars cause some of the most powerful explosions in the Universe.  For example, white dwarf stars explode at the end of their lives as Supernovae, when they ignite a runaway nuclear reaction.  These explosions can be seen at great distances and are important for measuring the expansion of the Universe.   These hot explosions expel ionized iron, nickel and other metals into space, leaving behind dense neutron stars.  Neutron stars can also explode by merger of two neutron stars. This explosion is very different, and creates very heavy elements, like gold and barium.  Neutron star mergers have recently been discovered with the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO). The investigator will estimate the rate of neutron star mergers by sensitive observations of the amounts of barium, iron and other metals in nearby galaxies.  The investigator's goal is to understand which types of explosions have created the elements found on Earth and throughout the Universe.

High school students will participate in this research during the summer. The investigator will encourage the inclusion of new groups of students by offering stipends.  The investigator also plans to implement tiers of mentoring.  Faculty will mentor postdocs, who will mentor graduate students.  The graduate students will mentor undergraduate students, who will mentor high school students.  This strategy has been shown to encourage younger students to pursue research careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The elements of the periodic table are created in the explosions of stars.  Different types of stars explode differently, and even the same type of star can explode differently in different conditions.  The diversity of explosions yields the full diversity of elements in the periodic table.  This research investigated the origins of some of the elements of the periodic table.

Elements in the iron peak, such as manganese and nickel, come from exploding white dwarfs, called Type Ia supernovae.  Our unique finding is that white dwarfs of any mass can explode.  They do not have to be very massive.  We made this discovery because we found a dearth of manganese and nickel in galaxies, whereas massive white dwarfs should produce copious iron-peak elements when they explode.

We also found that the heaviest elements of the periodic table come from a variety of sources.  We especially focused on globular clusters, which are dense concentrations of old stars.  We found that the first stars to form in a cluster show a wide diversity in the concentration of the heaviest elements, whereas the later-forming stars have a uniform composition of heavy elements.  We interpreted this finding in the context of gas mixing.  Consider adding salt to a pot of soup.  Before you mix the soup, some parts are very salty, and some parts are bland.  Likewise, a stellar explosion enriched the globular cluster with heavy elements inhomogeneously at first.  Eventually, the gas attained a uniform composition as it mixed evenly over time.  This result might require that the heavy elements in globular clusters come from the explosions of very massive stars.  This result is interesting because previous studies that involved gravitational waves found that at least one source of the heavy elements is the collision of neutron stars.  Therefore, we have found tentative evidence for multiple sources of the heavy elements.

This research required innovation of new spectroscopic techniques and instruments.  We have prepared extensively for the Subaru Prime Focus Spectrograph survey, which will begin in February 2025.  That survey will measure the compositions of hundreds of thousands of stars in the nearby universe.  We also have designed and built upgraded components for an existing spectrograph, DEIMOS, on the Keck II telescope.  Those upgraded components will increase the efficiency of the spectrograph for the hundreds of astronomers who use it every year.

High school students participated directly in this research.  Students from Pasadena High School and various high schools in northern Indiana engaged in original research projects that directly advanced the research objectives described above.  The students wrote code, analyzed spectra, measured chemical abundances, and contributed to published papers.  We recruited students with an emphasis on high schools that do not ordinarily have access to similar programs.  The high school students worked alongside undergraduate students (both local students and summer visiting students), graduate students, and faculty.

We also participated in the Warrior-Scholar Project, which educates active-duty military personnel and veterans about four-year college.  We taught an abbreviated physics course, and we helped prepare them for the transition to college.  We started a new chapter of the Warrior-Scholar Project at the California Institute of Technology in 2020, and we contributed to the existing chapter at the University of Notre Dame in 2022-2024.
